Question: Remove white space from string without using trim method?: :given string is'_home sweet home__' if user enter the mode as 0 then o/p should be 'home sweet home__'if user enter the mode as 1 then o/p should be '_home sweet home'if user enter the mode as 2 then o/p should be 'home sweet home'.Codepublic static void main(String args[]){Scanner sc=new Scanner(System.in);System.out.println("Enter the String");String str=sc.nextLine();System.out.println("Enter the StringMode");String strMode= sc.nextLine();switch(){}i want to find total number of white spaces in the given string.
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Remove white space from string without using trim method?: :given string is'_home sweet home__' if user enter the mode as 0 then o/p should be 'home sweet home__'if user enter the mode as 1 then o/p should be '_home sweet home'if user enter the mode as 2 then o/p should be 'home sweet home'.Codepublic static void main(String args[]){Scanner sc=new Scanner(System.in);System.out.println("Enter the String");String str=sc.nextLine();System.out.println("Enter the StringMode");String strMode= sc.nextLine();switch(){}i want to find total number of white spaces in the given string.
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: <<<api>>>: StringTokenizer
<<<code>>>: 
```java
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, " ");
int count = 0;
while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
    st.nextToken();
    count++;
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The StringTokenizer class in Java is used to break a string into tokens. In this case, we are using it to count the number of white spaces in the string. The while loop continues until there are no more tokens (i.e., no more white spaces) in the string.

Please note that this code will not work as expected if the string contains multiple consecutive white spaces. It will count each one as a separate token. If you want to count multiple consecutive white spaces as one, you would need to modify the code to handle that.

Also, please note that the StringTokenizer class is deprecated in Java 9 and onwards. If you are using Java 9 or later, you should consider using the split() method of the String class instead.

For the mode part, you can use a switch-case statement to handle different modes. Here is a simple example:

```java
switch (strMode) {
    case "0":
        // do nothing
        break;
    case "1":
        str = str.replaceFirst("^\\s+", "");
        break;
    case "2":
        str = str.replaceAll("\\s+", "");
        break;
    default:
        System.out.println("Invalid mode");
        break;
}
```

In this code, the switch-case statement checks the value of strMode. If it is "0", it does nothing. If it is "1", it removes the first white space from the string. If it is "2", it removes all white spaces from the string. If it is any other value, it prints "Invalid mode".

Please note that the replaceFirst() and replaceAll() methods in Java are case sensitive. If you want to remove white spaces regardless of their case, you can use replaceFirst("\\s+", "") and replaceAll("\\s+", "") instead.
